instruction: Routine vital signs (HR, BP, RR, SpO2) are performed every two hours.
On vasoactive drugs, BP and HR are performed q 15 minutes if titrating then, once stable, can shift to q 1 to 2 hours.
Vital signs on new admission are documented q15 min x 4, q30 min x 4, and q1h x 4.
Temperature is done q4h if afebrile; q30min - q1h if hypothermic; q2h if hyperthermic.
CVP/ PAP is assessed and documented q2h.
CO/CI is performed and documented every 8 hours and PRN with treament/intervention.
CCO documented every 2 hours. Calibrate SvO2/ScvO2 daily and PRN.
SvO2/ScVO2 done every 1-2 hours and PRN.
For IABP, aortic pressures and augmented pressures are performed q1h for stable patients when not titrating vasoactive medications, or q15 min and PRN as determined by individual patient status.
Aortic root MAP is used for hemodynamic calculations and titration of infusions.
IABP trigger, mode, and inflation frequency are documented q shift and with any changes in setting and PRN.
IABP alarm settings and Helium tank are assessed and documented q shift and PRN.
Assisted aortic pressures are asessed and documented q1h and PRN.
Unassisted aortic pressures are assessed and documented q4h and PRN.
For an IABP,  neurovascular checks: q15 min x 1 hour, then q30 min x 1 hour, then q1h and PRN.
HOB will remain < 30° during IABP therapy to prevent migration and kinking of the IAB catheter. May place patient in reverse Trendelenburg for comfort.
Logroll patient q2h to turn and change position.
Maintain 2 sets of ECG leads on patient: One set directly to the bedside monitor and one set directly to the IABP console.
Change the IABP electrodes q24h.
IABP trigger mode is always ECG or as determined by individual patient status.

Auto mode is preferred, with semi-auto used to assess timing and selected when auto mode does not provide appropriate timing or when there is no dicrotic notch on the arterial waveform (i.e. CPS and VAD patients).
Change IAB pressure tubing and pressure bag q96h or more frequently as determined by individual patient need.
Helium tank will be checked at the beginning of the shift and PRN for patients with IABP therapy.
If blood leak occurs, stop pumping immediately, and notify Cardiologist or Cardiac Surgeon for prompt IAB catheter removal.
The IAB catheter is removed by a Cardiologist, Cardiac Surgeon, or Nurse Practitioner with privileges to do so. The RN will not remove the IAB catheter.
Blood samples will not be drawn from the IAB catheter.
Pressure bag will be hung above the level of the heart (at least 3 feet), on a dedicated pole labeled 'Aortic root: No blood draws.'

Fiberoptic Catheter: The transducer will not be connected to the monitor for fiberoptic IABCs. If the fiberoptics are unable to read aortic root pressures or the IABC is not fiberoptic, use the traditional pressure monitoring system via the transducer.
An additional pressure line must be connected and transduced to the sheath stopcock if sheath sideport is present.
The aortic root will be kept free of air bubbles and clots.
If the patient is not on anticoagulation, VTE prophylaxis must be instituted as ordered by the provider.
Cardiovascular, including hemodynamic status and peripheral neurovascular assessment will be performed q1h and as determined by individual patient status.
With IABP, it is especially important to monitor the affected lower extremity, both upper extremities, and urine output.

Initial nursing assessment will include: IABP trigger & frequency, Waveform and waveform interpretation, Timing, Helium tank check, Console alarms check. Critical and advisory alarms must be on and audible, including augmentation alarm.

Reassessment throughout the shift will include: Unexpected patient outcomes, Interventions and patient response to interventions, Confirmation of IAB catheter location (x-ray confirmation per radiologist).
Assess patient with IABP therapy for adequate nutrition and any skin issues and obtain consult if required.
LVAD Flow, Speed, Pulsatility Index (PI), and Mode are assesed and charted q1 - 2h and PRN.
For the LVAD patient, obtain BP manually at least once per shift to validate automatic BP cuff result (unless patient has an arterial line).
P (performance) level, flow, placement signal, pump position, purge pressure, purge solution and infusion rate, motor current, and pump safety checks are performed q1h and PRN.
For an IABP,  neurovascular checks: q15 min x 1 hour, then q30 min x 1 hour, then q1h and PRN.
O2 therapy and vent settings are documented q shift and PRN with changes.

Continuous SpO2 is documented every q2h and PRN
a. Use non-dominant ring or middle finger (1st choice) or dominant ring or middle finger (2nd choice)
b. Avoid any devices that can impede blood flow to the sensor site (e.g., BP cuff).

Special considertion is made to correlate SpO2 with ABG when possible and to use non-dominant ring or middle finger (1st choice) or dominant ring or middle finger (2nd choice) and avoid any devices that can impede blood flow to the sensor site (e.g., BP cuff) as well as oid nail polish, artificial/long nails, anatomically abnormal fingers as they can lead to erroneous SpO2 measurements.
End-tidal CO2 monitoring is documented with vital signs and with any clinically significant changes.
ETT marker measurement is done at the lip and assessed at the beginning of each shift and after changing ETT position and/or securing device.
Intake (e.g., IV, enteral, flush, water, PO) is documented q1h.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: Urine output is measured and documented q1 - 2h while foley catheter is in place.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: NG  output is documented q12h or as determined by individual patient status. Advisable to document before 0600 and 1800 for shift totals.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: CRRT (SLED, SCUF) totals are documented q1h.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: For CRRT/SLED, arterial, venous, and transmembrane (TMP) pressures, blood flow rate, dialysate rate (if applicable), ultrafiltration rate, and ultrafiltration volume removed will be documented q1h.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: For CAPD, document the type of dialysate documented with every indwell. Upon admission, identify name of dialysate and frequency of treatment. If patient is receiving a dialysate that is known to contain interfering substances simultaneously, obtain baseline venous and capillary blood glucose values to determine accuracy. Document amount of effluent after each CAPD cycle.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: For PUF, document blood pump flow rate, fluid removal rate, infusion pressure and volume removed q1h.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: Document each occurrence of a bowel movement.
policy: SHC P&P 34706.01- Renal Replacement Therapy, SHC P&P 30053.01- Continuous Ambulatory Peritoneal Dialysis, SHC P&P 34740.99 – Peripheral Ultrafiltration/Aquapheresis

instruction: Upon admission, neurological assessment frequency is done every shift or with change in status.
policy: SHC P&P 34023.01 – Intracranial Pressure Monitoring: Set-up & Maintenance, SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: If patient has change in status, assess patient q1h x4, then q2h and PRN or per physician order.
policy: SHC P&P 34023.01 – Intracranial Pressure Monitoring: Set-up & Maintenance, SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Intracranial Monitoring (ICP/CPP/PbO2) is done q1h & PRN.
policy: SHC P&P 34023.01 – Intracranial Pressure Monitoring: Set-up & Maintenance, SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Dysphagia screen is to be done on all stroke patients prior to administering any oral fluids or medications.
policy: SHC P&P 34023.01 – Intracranial Pressure Monitoring: Set-up & Maintenance, SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Post cardiac arrest neurologic monitoring: Follow recommendations for neurologic monitoring, including pupillometry, as outlined in SHC P&P 34308.99 – ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest.
policy: SHC P&P 34023.01 – Intracranial Pressure Monitoring: Set-up & Maintenance, SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Perform Joint/Co-Neurological assessment for patients admitted for neurological disorder and for patients exhibiting acute onset of neurological deficits with the oncoming and off going nurses at change-of-shift and upon transfer.

Co-Neurological assessment includes: neurological symptoms, level of consciousness, pupils (size, description, reaction), orientation, characteristics of speech/communication, facial expression & symmetry, extremity (motor, strength, tone and sensation), and GCS.
For stroke, TIA or possible stroke diagnosis, include baseline NIHSS score.
Notify provider with any significant neuro change from patient's baseline.
Initiate analgesia and sedation prior to administering paralytic.
Document 'Assumed Pain Present' in pain assessment flowsheet in lieu of CPOT when patient is on neuromuscular blockade.
Ensure patient's RASS is -4 to -5 prior to initiating Neuromuscular blocking agent infusion.
If available, use Bispectral Index Monitor (BIS) monitoring for sedation adequacy; goal 40-60.
Peripheral Nerve Stimulation (PNS) and Train-of-Four (TOF) should be used to establish baseline TOF whenever possible. This is the baseline energy level to be used for all future tests.
Baseline measurement should be completed and documented in EMR prior to initiation of paralytic to determine frequency at which patient has 4/4 twitches.
Sites for TOF testing include: (1) (preferred site): Ulnar nerve, (2) Posterior Tibial, and (3) Facial nerve.
Use PNS and TOF to assess appropriate level of blockade, with goal of 1-2/4 twitches or as ordered.
Assess TOF 10-15 mins after bolus or change in continuous infusion rate.
Assess TOF q 4 hrs when patient is at desired level of blockade.
Change electrodes as needed. Increase in electrical stimulation may be needed if patient has increase in swelling.
Eye lubricant will be applied q4h and PRN, eyelids kept closed when patient is unable to blink or completely close eyes, or pharmacological paralytics or is heavily sedated.
policy:
Mosby's Skills (Marshall, A.P. (2008). Eye care in the critically ill: Clinical practice guideline. Aust Crit Care, 21(2), 97-109), Mosby’s Skills - Seizure
Precautions

instruction: Eye care includes cleaning with saline-soaked gauze and administration of an eye-specific lubricant.
policy:
Mosby's Skills (Marshall, A.P. (2008). Eye care in the critically ill: Clinical practice guideline. Aust Crit Care, 21(2), 97-109), Mosby’s Skills - Seizure
Precautions

instruction: Seizure precautions will be instituted for patients with an actual seizure disorder and will include the following: Side rails up and padded, and oral airway at HOB if not intubated.
policy:
Mosby's Skills (Marshall, A.P. (2008). Eye care in the critically ill: Clinical practice guideline. Aust Crit Care, 21(2), 97-109), Mosby’s Skills - Seizure
Precautions

instruction: Pupillometer monitoring is recommended for patients with high risk for neurologic deterioration or per provider order, such as: Cerebral edema, Minor (GCS13-15), Moderate (GCS 9-12), severe head injuries (GCS ≤ 8), Increasing intracranial pressure, Patient with ICP monitoring, Subarachnoid hemorrhage from aneurysmal rupture or malformation, Intracerebral hemorrhage, Ischemic strokes, Neurosurgical procedures, Post cardiac arrest, Sedated or pharmacologically paralyzed patients, Difficult to assess pupils (i.e. high dose sedation, pinpoint pupils), Any patient requiring close monitoring of pupillary assessment, As directed by P&P 34308.99 for neuroprognostication after cardiac arrest.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Perform baseline pupillometer assessment.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Assess pupillometer with neuro checks or per provider order.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Assess both pupils with pupillometer.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Document NPI (Neurological Pupil index), Size (resting pupil size), MIN (pupil size at peak of constriction) for each eye.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: Collaborate with provider for abnormal pupillometer changes and or findings: Change in pupil size < 10% before and after light stimulation, Unequal pupils, difference > 1 mm, NPI < 3 or decreasing trend, NPI difference ≥ 0.7.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual; SHC P&P 34308.99 ICU Neuroprognostication Protocol after Cardiac Arrest

instruction: For Post Tenecteplase (TNKase)/Endovascular Therapy (EVT) Stroke patients, the frequency of vital signs, neuro checks, and bleeding assessment will be q15min x 2 hrs from time of TNKase/EVT, q30min x 6 hrs, then q1hr x 16hrs.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For Endovascular Therapy (EVT) Stroke patients, groin site and peripheral pulses will be done Q15min x 4, q30min x 2, then q1hr x4, then routine.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For Ischemic Stroke Thrombolysis: vital signs, neuro checks, angioedema assessment and bleeding assessment will be done q15min x 2 hrs, q30 min x 6 hrs, then q1hr x 16 hrs.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For Hemorrhagic Stroke (Intracerebral Hemorrhage, Subarachnoid Hemorrhage), vital signs and neuro checks will be done q15min x 4, q30min x 2, then Q1hr.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For patients with a diagnosis of Stroke/TIA or possible stroke, nurse will perform and document a bedside nursing swallow screen upon admission (if not done in ED), with any change in LOC, and upon transfer from another facility. Keep NPO until bedside nursing swallow screen is performed and passed before giving food, liquids or medications. Document appropriately.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For patients with a diagnosis of Stroke/TIA or possible stroke, monitor blood glucose POC AC/HS as dictated by order set, including both diabetics and non-diabetics with a goal of BG < 180 for 3 days.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For patients with a diagnosis of Stroke/TIA or possible stroke, consider antipyretics, by MD order, for temp > 37.5
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: Perform and document full NIHSS upon admission, each shift, and PRN with neurological changes and upon discharge.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: For patients with a diagnosis of stroke/TIA or possible stroke, unless contraindicated implement DVT prophylaxis measures as ordered by physician and/or by Day 2 of admission.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: Provide patient and family with stroke education, including individualized risk factors and smoking cessation. Document education provided in EMR. Compare Home Medication List, MAR, discharge orders/prescriptions and Stroke Core Measures to ensure patient is being discharged with the appropriate medications.
policy: Care of the Patient With Acute Ischemic Stroke (Endovascular/Intensive Care Unit - Postinterventional Therapy): Update to the 2009 Comprehensive Nursing Care, AHA Scientific Statement, Stroke Ischemic Post Alteplase (TPA) Admission Order Set, Stroke Ischemic Thrombolysis Order Set

instruction: Pulmonary artery and arterial pressure waveform must be continuously displayed on the monitor.

Transducer will be leveled at mid-anterior/posterior (A/P) at the 4th intercostal space every shift and PRN. Keep HOB < 60° for all pressure measurements. Cardiac output will be measured with HOB < 60°.
Zero the pressure lines q shift, when set-up is changed, waveform changes, and PRN with opening of the system.
Dynamic response ('snap test') will be performed q shift and PRN with changes in waveform configuration.
Standard normal saline flush solution will be used.
Pressure line (except ICP and lumbar drains) will have pressure bag inflated and maintained at 300 mmHg. The flush bag along with transducer setups will be changed q96h (including extension tubing).

Perform line reconciliation for all pressure monitoring lines and devices q shift and prn including the following steps: Trace pressure monitoring lines beginning at pressure bag, to the transducer tubing system, all the way to the patient, Ensure all connections are secured. Ensure the flush bag contains solution to maintain catheter patency and pressure bag is inflated to 300mmHg.

Maximum barriers are used for line insertion. MD must wear cap, mask, sterile gloves, sterile gown and others in the room must wear cap and mask during line insertion. A time out is completed, and the procedure note is used to document the insertion.
All pressure readings will be done at end-expiration.
Arterial pressure waveforms must ALWAYS be displayed on the monitor.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Arterial insertion sites and surrounding area will be assessed q shift and PRN for signs of infection, bleeding or hematoma.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: For (radial) arterial catheter removal, manual pressure is applied after removal and provider notified STAT if the extremity becomes swollen, cold, and pulseless or discolored, or any signs or symptoms of bleeding occur.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: For radial arterial line removal, apply manual pressure for a minimum of 5 min or until bleeding stops following line removal.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: For femoral (monitoring catheter or sheath), apply manual pressure or use Femostop for minimum of 30 minutes following removal, or until bleeding stops and hemostasis is achieved.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Arterail insertion sites will then be dressed with sterile 2x2 and transparent dressing. Patient will remain on bedrest with HOB < 30° x 6 hrs.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: If both arterial and venous sheaths are present, the arterial sheath is removed first, then venous sheath.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: After arterial line removal, complete neurovascular and site checks q15min x4, q30min x2, q1h x4, PRN or as ordered by provider.
policy: SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: During insertion of pulmonary artery catheter insertion, note and/or record waveform values obtained during insertion.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Document pulmonary artery catheter insertion mark on Lines and Tubes Assessment in Cerner. Document waveforms.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Obtain post-pulmonary artery catheter insertion chest x-ray.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Pulmonary artery waveforms must ALWAYS be monitored.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: If waveform changes to permanent wedge (PCWP): Reposition patient and if waveforms still looks like in wedge (PCWP) position make sure balloon is deflated. Notify provider. If ordered, RN may withdraw catheter slightly until appearance of PA waveform.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: If RV waveform noted on monitor, the provider must be notified and if ordered, the nurse can withdraw catheter slightly until appearance of RA waveform.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Obtaining a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) will be performed only with physician order.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Use only the syringe that is manufactured for PA catheter for balloon inflation. The syringe and balloon should be kept empty of air and the valve kept closed when not in use.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: For CCO (Continuous Cardiac Output), calibrate SvO2 monitors within 2 hours of admission to the unit, as determined by individual patient status, and daily. Update hemoglobin if value changes by 1.8 g/dL.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Transducer for pulmonary artery catheter will be leveled at mid-anterior/posterior (A/P) at the 4th intercostal space q shift and PRN.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: Pulmonary artery catheter insertion site will be covered with an occlusive and transparent dressing with Biopatch.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, PA Catheter Troubleshooting Guide

instruction: In relation to BP and LVAD, use Doppler pressure with change in patient status.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Assess and document LVAD drive line site and dressing at least every shift.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Ensure that drive line is free from pulling on drive line site.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Ensure that patient has LVAD Extra Controller and extra power source at bedside and with them at all times.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Unless otherwise ordered, follow drive line site care policy for dressing care instructions using sterile technique.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Perform system test on System Controller and Power Module q24h.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: For LVAD, never disconnect both power leads at the same time (Will lead to external power loss).
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: For all transport events (LVAD) off the unit, take two extra batteries and an extra System Controller.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Consult with Mechanical Circulatory Support team as needed 858-939-3863.
policy: SHC P&P 34715.01 – Ventricular Assist Device: Driveline Site Care

instruction: Patients with femorally placed Impella are on complete bedrest with HOB < 30 degrees, affected leg immobilized. May use reverse Trendelenburg position to elevate HOB for VAP prevention.
Change Dextrose containing purge solution bag q24h.
Change purge cassette q5days (must be done in less than 2 minutes to prevent damage to the catheter).
Monitor: Correct pump placement. If pump repositioning is required, decrease P (performance) level to P2 before MD repositions.
For Impella, monitor purge pressure.
For Impella, monitor flow. Do not reduce flow < 0.5 L/min.
For Impella, monitor flow. Flow should correlate with P level. If not, suspect suction. If suction suspected, decrease P level by 1 - 2, check position, and assess patient's fluid status.
Monitor Impella site for signs or symptoms of infection or bleeding. Maintain catheter insertion angle with all dressing changes.
Maintain backup Impella AIC controller plugged in on unit.
Weaning of Impella support is coordinated with physician. Wean P level by 2 q2 - 3 hrs. Decrease to P1 and MD will pull catheter into the aorta. Decrease to P0 as MD removes catheter.
Decrease P level to 0 for removal.

keywords: impella dressing change initiated in or
instruction: Impella 5.5: Initial dressing change will be removed and using the Centurion Driveline Securement System with large Biopatch, the dressing will be changed unless initiated in OR.
Impella 5.5: If bleeding noted at site, MD will be notified to address additional suture placement. If not appropriate, absorbable hemostat material (i.e., Surgiseal) may be placed for oozing.
Impella 5.5: After anchoring dressing is placed at site, additional securement of the catheter will be done with anchoring device.
Impella 5.5: Dressing will be changed weekly and when wet, loose, or soiled.

keywords: impella upper extremity not above 90 degrees
instruction: Axillary placed Impella 5.5: Mobility guideline with axillary placement: Affected upper extremity should not be raised above 90 degrees. Prior to patient mobilizing, ensure device is secured, Tuohy borst valve is screwed down and catheter has securement anchor.

Axillary placed Impella 5.5: If patient getting out of bed, check insertion markers before and after ambulation. If measurement and waveform has changed after ambulation, notify MD and obtain echo for placement confirmation.
Transvenous pacemaker: Assess and document site and external centimeter marking of the pacemaker at the introducer exit site q shift and PRN.
Transvenous pacemaker: Do not use side port or introducer sheath for IV infusions or blood draws. Infusions may be allowed for emergencies as long as patency is established.
Transvenous pacemaker: Removal should be done by physician, physician assistant, or nurse practitioner.
Epicardial Wires: Assess and document pacing wires and insertion site every shift.
Epicardial Wires: Change and document dressing daily and PRN.

Removal of pacing wires: vital signs (BP, HR, O2 sat) and heart sounds assessed and documented pre-removal then every 15 minutes x 1hr then routine. Patient will remain on bedrest for 1 hour. Assess for arrhythmia and signs of cardiac tamponade.
Document date and time of initiation of pacemaker therapy, events warranting therapy, VS, ECG, and hemodynamic parameters prior to initiating therapy and patient response.

keywords: pacemaker settings ma mv mode rate
instruction: Assess and document every shift and with initiation: epicardial wire location/dressing, pacemaker type, Percent pacing, all pacemaker settings (mA, mV, mode, and rate), patient and family education.
Underlying Rhythms: Assess and document as needed or as determined by individual patient status (every shift in the ICU). Assessed by decreasing pacemaker rate or pausing the temporary pacemaker.
Determine stimulation thresholds and document at the time of insertion and as determined by individual patient status (every shift in the ICU). Determine sensitivity threshold PRN only.
Safety considerations: Wear gloves whenever contacting the pacing wires.

keywords: pulse generator kept out of reach
instruction: Safety considerations: The pulse generator will be locked and kept out of patient's immediate reach.

keywords: ensure connections secure q shift prn
instruction: Safety considerations: Ensure connections are secure every shift and PRN.
For temporary pacemeker, check battery level and maintain extra batteries at bedside
Standby definition – Pacemaker is connected to the patient and OFF.
Backup definition-pacemaker is on, connected to the patient, and set to a rate lower than the patient’s native rate.
Insulated and isolated pacing wires using nonconductive material, applied for easy accessibility. Label dressing with number and type of wires.
Assess vital signs, groin/puncture sites and neurovascular status immediately upon arrival from procedural area, then Q15min x4, Q30 min x4, then Q2h.
Perform neurological checks immediately upon arrival from procedural area, then Q15min x4, Q30min x4, then Q2h.
Measure circumference of affected extremities Q2h and mark measurement lines if applicable.
Maintain complete bedrest and HOB no more than 15 degrees.
Perform appropriate skin breakdown prevention measures.
Apply manual pressure if bleeding develops at puncture site and notify appropriate provider.
Change or reinforce puncture site dressings as necessary.

Notify appropriate provider for the following: SBP <100 or >180, DBP >100, Temp >38.3C (101F), If Hgb falls by 2 grams, If Fibrinogen <100mg/dL, Any changes in pulses, degree of pain, monitor/sensory function, increased firmness and/or limb circumference f. ANY neurological changes, Any bleeding.
No IM injections, suppositories, or blade shaving.
Monitor labs (e.g., CBC, PT, PTT, INR, Fibrinogen, etc...) as ordered.
Ensure that ultrasound-assisted device is plugged in and charging at all times (if in use).
Change of caregiver handover to include line reconciliation and neuro/neurovascular joint assessment.
Medication: DO NOT piggyback any drip or medication into Heparin or TPA lines.
Medication: Use dedicated IV pole for Heparin and TPA infusions.
Medication: If anticoagulant infusion completed before line removed collaborate with provider and pharmacy for appropriate fluid and rate to continue through catheter.

Medication: Discontinue IM injections, suppositories, aspirin containing meds, antiplatelets [e.g., clopidogrel (Plavix), prasugrel (Effient)], anticoagulants [e.g., warfarin (Coumadin), dabigatran (Pradaxa), rivaroxaban (Xarelto), apixaban (Eliquis)], and all NSAIDS.
ETT will be repositioned and secured with an approved device q12 - 24h and PRN (or per facility standard).
policy: SHC P&P 44220.99 – Tube Cuff: Care of the Endotracheal/Tracheostomy, SCVMC Ventilator Management and Patient Assessment Department Guidelines, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Position of ETT (e.g. level at lips/teeth) will be maintained at all times and documented q shift.
policy: SHC P&P 44220.99 – Tube Cuff: Care of the Endotracheal/Tracheostomy, SCVMC Ventilator Management and Patient Assessment Department Guidelines, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: The following areas will be documented with each change of position: Condition of surrounding skin, Location of tube after repositioning, Any complications.
policy: SHC P&P 44220.99 – Tube Cuff: Care of the Endotracheal/Tracheostomy, SCVMC Ventilator Management and Patient Assessment Department Guidelines, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Cuff pressure measurement will be checked q shift and PRN.
policy: SHC P&P 44220.99 – Tube Cuff: Care of the Endotracheal/Tracheostomy, SCVMC Ventilator Management and Patient Assessment Department Guidelines, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Patient with a 'critical' airway: will be identified with a sign posted above the HOB and the risk will be communicated during shift handoff.
policy: SHC P&P 44220.99 – Tube Cuff: Care of the Endotracheal/Tracheostomy, SCVMC Ventilator Management and Patient Assessment Department Guidelines, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: A Sedation Awakening Trial (SAT) will be performed twice daily on all mechanically ventilated patients unless contraindicated.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: SAT contraindications: On a neuromuscular blocking agent, On a continuous infusion for controlling active seizures, treating alcohol withdrawal, or increased ICP, Open chest, Documented myocardial ischemia within the last 24 hours.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Goal is to reduce the use of sedation and/or analgesia until the Richmond Agitation - Sedation Scale (RASS) is 0 to -1 or until the patient is off continuous infusions of sedatives and/or opiates/analgesics: Turn off the sedative infusion first, Wean narcotic infusion dose by 50 - 100% q30 min, If patient complains or demonstrates signs/symptoms of pain while the continuous narcotic infusion is shut off, the RN will administer bolus doses of opiates as needed.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Vital Signs: Assess q30 min; Stop SAT if any of the following are present for 5 minutes or longer: SaO2 < 88%, RR > 35 breaths/min, New acute cardiac dysrhythmia.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Stop SAT if any of the following are present for 5 minutes or longer: Heart rate increase of 20 or more bpm, Use of accessory muscles, Systolic BP of 20% change from baseline.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: If the patient does not tolerate due to change in vital signs: Restart opiate/analgesic infusion at 50% of the prior dose, Titrate to RASS of 0 to -1 using intermittent boluses, Do not restart sedative unless absolutely necessary (if absolutely necessary, restart at 50% of prior dose).
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Assess for presence of pain or delirium when patient awakens using the CAM-ICU.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Collaborate with RCP to screen for and begin Spontaneous Breathing Trial (SBT).
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: If the patient fails SBT, patient will be returned to the previous mode of ventilation with settings to ensure patient safety and comfort. Document the reason(s) for failure of SBT.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, San Diego Patient Safety Council: ICU Sedation Toolkit (2009), AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Extubation is a collaborative process between the RN, Respiratory Therapist, and Physician.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Weaning parameters will be assessed and documented by Respiratory Therapy and will be communicated to RN and physician if required.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Symptoms associated with independent breathing and adequate ventilation and oxygenation will be documented: baseline, q15 min, at conclusion of Spontaneous Breathing Trial (SBT) and post extubation/decannulation: SpO2 and FiO2, RR, HR, BP, Increase WOB (Accessory Muscles), Increased agitation and anxiety.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

keywords: patient fails sbt return previous mode
instruction: If the patient fails SBT, return the patient to the previous mode of ventilation with settings to ensure patient safety and comfort.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Obtain Physician order prior to extubation/decannulation procedure.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Prior to extubation, education will be provided to the patient/family. The patient must have an effective cough and able to maintain a patent airway for extubation to occur.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Post Extubation/Decannulation Monitoring: Assess the patient for evidence of laryngospasm or bronchospasm.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Post Extubation/Decannulation Monitoring: Continue to assess patient's respiratory status as determined by the individual patient status or need.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

keywords: report changes patient status post extubation
instruction: Post Extubation/Decannulation Monitoring: Maintain effective communication and report changes in patient status or unexpected outcomes: HR, RR and BP increase of greater than 10% of baseline, SpO2 < 90%, Stridor, breathing difficulty, chest-abdominal asynchrony, Patient unable to manage secretions, or ineffective cough.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: Post Extubation/Decannulation Monitoring: Assess swallowing ability for potential problems; notify physician if pt has difficulty swallowing, choking on liquids etc.
policy: SHC P&P 44239.99 – Weaning (Liberation) from Mechanical Ventilation, AACN Procedure Manual

keywords: no action unless serum glucose elevations
instruction: Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG < 125 mg/dL: No additional screening for patients with no history of diabetes. RN Action: No action needed unless serum glucose elevations in routine chemistry panel.

keywords: no action unless serum glucose high
instruction: Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG 125-180 mg/dl: For All Subsequent Blood Glucose Checks - Drops to less than 125 mg/dL. RN Action: Stop screening and no action needed unless serum glucose high in routine chemistry panel.

Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG 125-180 mg/dl: For All Subsequent Blood Glucose Checks - If trending down, but remains greater than 125 mg/dL. RN Action: Continue screening q2h until less than 125 mg/dL.

Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG 125-180 mg/dl: For All Subsequent Blood Glucose Checks - If trending up to greater than 150 mg/dL. RN Action: Call Physician to request insulin orders, Continuous Insulin Infusion (CII) is recommended.

Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG 125-180 mg/dl: For All Subsequent Blood Glucose Checks - If greater than 180 mg/dL. RN Action: Call Physician to request insulin orders, Continuous Insulin Infusion (CII) is recommended.
Upon admission or transfer into the ICU - Initial ICU BG ≥ 180 mg/dl: RN Action: Call Physician to request insulin orders, Continuous Insulin Infusion (CII) is recommended.

keywords: do not increase goal rate bg > 180
instruction: Enteral Feedings: If POC BG >180mg/dL x 2 consecutively in 24 hours, do not increase to goal rate until two consecutive BG <181mg/dL in 24 hours.
Document q1h the arterial, venous, and transmembrane (TMP) pressures, blood flow rate, dialysate rate (if applicable), ultrafiltration rate, and ultrafiltration volume removed.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.99

instruction: Use of hemodialysis shunts or AV fistulas is not recommended for Renal Replacement Therapy access unless in an emergency because of risk of vascular injury, bleeding, and infection. Obtain alternative temporary access as soon as feasible.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.100

instruction: Dialysis catheters are used only for dialysis. If needed emergently, the Heparin plug will be removed first.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.101

keywords: do not use hemodialysis catheters lab draws
instruction: Do not use hemodialysis catheters for routine lab draws unless specifically ordered (decreases catheter lifespan).
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.102

instruction: When using Citrate anticoagulation, ensure that tri-sodium citrate solution is infused via access line into the circuit, and the calcium chloride solution is infused into another central IV access (preferred) or return line.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.103

instruction: Dialysis circuit will be changed q72h and PRN.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.104

instruction: Discontinuation of Renal Replacement Therapy: Follow SHC P&P 34708.01 when uncoupling catheter and Renal Replacement Therapy machine.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.105

instruction: Discontinuation of Renal Replacement Therapy: For catheter dwell (ie;Heparin 1000 units/mL or 4% citrate) prepare two syringes with volume written on catheter hub + 0.1mL to cover catheter tip.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.106

instruction: Discontinuation of Renal Replacement Therapy: If using outside dialysis services, notify HD RN on call that therapy has been discontinued.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, SHC P&P 34706.01 – Renal Replacement Therapies, SHC P&P 34708.01 - Hemodialysis Catheter: Uncoupling & Maintenance, SHC P&P 30601.01 – Central Venous, Arterial, & Midline Catheter: Dressing Change, SHC P&P Priming NxStage 34305.107

instruction: Refer patients to LifeSharing with a Glasgow Coma Scale < 4 or those with a grim prognosis.
policy: SHC P&P 01831 – Withholding/Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, SHC P&P 30060.99 – End-of-Life Care, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: It is the role of the LifeSharing coordinator to contact the family and discuss the option of organ donation in the case of brain death or the option of donation after cardiac death.
policy: SHC P&P 01831 – Withholding/Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, SHC P&P 30060.99 – End-of-Life Care, AACN Procedure Manual

instruction: If the patient is to be a Coroner's Case, ensure that family understands this, and how this will affect process after death - maintaining lines and tubes, body removed by medical examiner.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, Kirchhoff, K., Kowalkowski, J., (2010) Current Practices for Withdrawal of Life Support in Intensive Care Units, American Journal of Critical Care, Vol 19, no. 6, Nov. 2010, Nelson, P. (2010), Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Therapies, Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association, Stacy, K. ( 2012) Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, Critical Care Nurse, Vol 32, no. 3, 14-23.

instruction: Ensure that orders are written for FULL DNR, withdrawal of life support, and for comfort measures - analgesia, anxiolytic infusions. The alleviation of pain and distressing symptoms now drives all further interventions.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, Kirchhoff, K., Kowalkowski, J., (2010) Current Practices for Withdrawal of Life Support in Intensive Care Units, American Journal of Critical Care, Vol 19, no. 6, Nov. 2010, Nelson, P. (2010), Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Therapies, Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association, Stacy, K. ( 2012) Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, Critical Care Nurse, Vol 32, no. 3, 14-23.

instruction: Notify LifeSharing.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, Kirchhoff, K., Kowalkowski, J., (2010) Current Practices for Withdrawal of Life Support in Intensive Care Units, American Journal of Critical Care, Vol 19, no. 6, Nov. 2010, Nelson, P. (2010), Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Therapies, Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association, Stacy, K. ( 2012) Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, Critical Care Nurse, Vol 32, no. 3, 14-23.

instruction: If patient is on a neuromuscular blocking agent, discontinue the infusion and allow effect to wear off. The goal is to have the TOF 2/4.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, Kirchhoff, K., Kowalkowski, J., (2010) Current Practices for Withdrawal of Life Support in Intensive Care Units, American Journal of Critical Care, Vol 19, no. 6, Nov. 2010, Nelson, P. (2010), Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Therapies, Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association, Stacy, K. ( 2012) Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, Critical Care Nurse, Vol 32, no. 3, 14-23.

instruction: If patient has an internal defibrillator, the defibrillator function may be turned off by placing a magnet over the device.
policy: Harrington MD, Luebke, D., Lewis, W., Aulisio, M., Johnson, N. (n.d.) Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillators at End of Life, Fast Facts and Concepts #112. Wiegand, D., Kalowes, P., (2007), Withdrawal of Cardiac Medications and Devices, AACN Advanced Critical Care, Vol 18 no. 4, pgs 415-425.

keywords: monitor display off room central station
instruction: Turn off monitor alarms, and turn off monitor display in the room, keeping it on at the central station.
policy: AACN Procedure Manual, Kirchhoff, K., Kowalkowski, J., (2010) Current Practices for Withdrawal of Life Support in Intensive Care Units, American Journal of Critical Care, Vol 19, no. 6, Nov. 2010, Nelson, P. (2010), Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Therapies, Hospice and Palliative Nurses Association, Stacy, K. ( 2012) Withdrawal of Life-Sustaining Treatment, Critical Care Nurse, Vol 32, no. 3, 14-23.

instruction: Medications that are not in the withdrawal of care order set will be discontinued. Vasoactive drips are considered life support and should be turned off or rapidly titrated down so that the dying process is NOT prolonged.
policy: Harrington MD, Luebke, D., Lewis, W., Aulisio, M., Johnson, N. (n.d.) Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillators at End of Life, Fast Facts and Concepts #112. Wiegand, D., Kalowes, P., (2007), Withdrawal of Cardiac Medications and Devices, AACN Advanced Critical Care, Vol 18 no. 4, pgs 415-425.

instruction: Withdrawal of mechanical ventilation: Extubation may occur immediately (Immediate withdrawal), and patient may be extubated to room air or to a source of oxygen. Position the patient's head to facilitate airflow and minimize noisy respirations or other distressing sounds and remove the ventilator from the room.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

keywords: fio2 peep rate volume pressure support
instruction: Withdrawal of mechanical ventilation: Mechanical ventilation may also be weaned gradually (terminal weaning) by: Rapid reduction of vent settings, step-wise for FiO2, PEEP, rate, volume and pressure support every few minutes while watching for respiratory distress. If distress occurs, return to previous ventilator settings while titrating medications for comfort, then resume ventilator weaning.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

instruction: Withdrawal of mechanical ventilation: Once ventilator support weaned off, extubate patient to room air or oxygen and remove the ventilator from the room.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

keywords: removing ventilator placing t piece blow-by
instruction: Withdrawal of mechanical ventilation: If patient has a swollen, protuberant tongue, collaborate with physician and family regarding leaving the ETT in place, but removing the ventilator and placing patient on T piece or blow-by.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

keywords: t piece trach mask humidified air oxygen
instruction: Withdrawal of mechanical ventilation: If the patient has a tracheostomy, follow the steps above for weaning and discontinuing the ventilator and place the patient on a T piece or trach mask with humidified air or oxygen.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

keywords: bipap comfort measure end of life
patient comfort goal removal maintenance non-invasive ventilation
instruction: BiPap may be used as a comfort measure at end of life for patients with dyspnea who wish to decrease opioid use to treat the dyspnea. However, the mask may contribute to discomfort by causing claustrophobia, skin breakdown, and it makes conversation difficult. Again, allow the patient's comfort goal be your guide in the removal or maintenance of non-invasive ventilation.
policy: Yeow, M., Mehta, R., White, D., Szmuilowicz, E. Using Non-Invasive Ventilation at End of life, EPERC Fast Facts #230, n.d., Medical College of Wisconsin

keywords: pacemakers not turned off end of life
decision turn off pacemaker physician program
continued use icd inconsistent patient goals
withdrawal anti-arrhythmic medications turn off icd
instruction: Pacemaker/AICD: Pacemakers are not usually turned off at end of life because they will not prolong life in a patient dying of advanced disease. If a decision is made to turn off a pacemaker, this must be done by a physician able to program the device. A magnet or a company representative can stop the ICD function of a Pacer/AICD with a physician order. Indications for deactivation of ICD therapy include: Continued use of an ICD is inconsistent with patient goals, Withdrawal of anti-arrhythmic medications: if anti-arrhythmic medications are withdrawn consider turning off the ICD to avoid frequent shocks, Imminent death, The patient has a DNR order. The functioning of an ICD is generally inconsistent with a 'Do-Not-Resuscitate' order since ICDs attempt to resuscitate the patient by shocking their hearts back into a life-sustaining rhythm.
policy: Harrington MD, Luebke, D., Lewis, W., Aulisio, M., Johnson, N. (n.d.) Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillators at End of Life, Fast Facts and Concepts #112. Wiegand, D., Kalowes, P., (2007), Withdrawal of Cardiac Medications and Devices, AACN Advanced Critical Care, Vol 18 no. 4, pgs 415-425.

keywords: collaborate provider mcs team family stopping pump
instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: Notify MCS Team of impending EOL Care (if available), Identify if autopsy will be needed, Collaborate with provider, MCS team, and family on stopping of pump.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller

keywords: pump alarm low flow silence alarms
instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: If family wants to wait until cessation of respirations, inform them that pump will alarm for low flow, and silence alarms as needed.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller

keywords: remove controller cell both power lines
open driveline lock disconnect driveline controller
instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: If family wants to stop pump, ensure patient is comfortable on analgesic and anxiolytic infusions, and remove controller cell and both power lines, open driveline lock and disconnect driveline from controller.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller

keywords: lvad stopped patient startle huge breath
does not indicate distress prepare family
instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: When the LVAD is stopped it is not uncommon to see the patient startle and take a huge breath or raise their arms. This is a physiological response and does not indicate distress and prepare family for this.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller

instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: Return all equipment of MCS Lab.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller

instruction: For patients with LVADs -- SMH Only: See Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller.
policy: Heartmate LVAD Resource Center Educational Materials, Withdrawal of Support Instructions to Stop Pump with Pocket Controller
